p: Biological invasions have severe impacts on biodiversity, community composition and ecosystem functions [ 1â€“ 5]. Invasive plants can alter many important ecosystem functions including the nitrogen cycle [ 6], carbon cycle, and decomposition. For example, invasion by the plant Amur Honeysuckle altered the decomposition rate in the invaded environment likely through changes in litter quality [ 7]. Exotic snails have been found to alter carbon and nitrogen fluxes in freshwater systems through their consumption/excretion activity [ 8]. These functions are provided by environmental microbiomes. Yet, despite the implications for ecosystem functioning, we are still learning the consequences of biological invasions on environmental microbiomes.
